sections.title: Section 1: Diving into AI First Java Programming

chapters.title: Chapter 1: Your First Java Program
chapters.goal: Build a simple application using an IDE and AI tooling and learn the syntax of Java that makes your program run.

examples.title: Hello World
examples.description: Write a simple Hello World program in Java.
examples.prompt: Write a Hello World program in Java.

chapters.title: Chapter 2: Dynamic Programming with Variables and Input
chapters.goal: Generate an application that you can interact with and learn how variables act as the memory of software programs.

examples.title: Variable Declaration
examples.description: Declare variables in Java to remember values for later.
examples.prompt: Create a reminder by declaring a String variable and print the reminder.
response: String reminder = "Don't forget to submit the report by 5 PM.";

examples.title: Print Number
examples.description: Create a Java program that displays a number variable.

prompts.prompt: Write code that prints a number variable.
Update the code to add two numbers and display their sum.

examples.title: Java Data Types: Short and Int
examples.description: Explore the differences between short and int data types in Java.
examples.prompt: Write intro code using both a short data type and an int data type.
response: int sum = shortValue + intValue;    // short promoted to int
short doubled = (short) (shortValue * 2); // cast back to short

examples.title: Java Data Types: Widening Type Casting
examples.description: Explore widening type casting in Java by converting integer variables to double in a calculation.
examples.prompt: Write code to calculate splitting the length of a piece of printer paper into 2 pieces, converting two integer variables to a double in the calculation.
response: int paperLengthInches = 11; // length of printer paper (US Letter long side)

examples.title: Java Data Types: Narrow Type Casting
examples.description: Explore narrowing type casting in Java by converting a double variable to an int.
examples.prompt: Write code to narrow casting by displaying an integer value of a price of $100.30 for an advertisement.
response: int adPrice = (int) price; // narrow casting from double to int

examples.title: Java Data Types: Float and Double
examples.description: Explore the differences between float and double data types in Java.
examples.prompt: Write intro code using both a float data type and a double data type.
response: double sum = f + d;              // float promoted to double
float narrowed = (float) d;      // explicit cast from double to float

examples.title: Java Data Types: Boolean
examples.description: Explore the boolean data type in Java.
examples.prompt: Write intro code using a boolean data type without using logic like an if statement.
response: // Combine booleans with logical operators (no if/switch/?:)

examples.title: Pizza Party Calculator
examples.description: Create a pizza calculator in Java that calculates the number of pizzas needed based on the number of people in a party and slices per pizza.
examples.prompt: Write a simple pizza calculator with variables for people in party and slices per pizza.

examples.title: Welcome {Name}
examples.description: Write a Welcome {Name} program in Java using a variable to store the name.
examples.prompt: Write a Welcome {Name} application without taking input.

examples.title: Welcome {Name} with Input
examples.description: Write a simple Welcome {Name} program in Java that takes the user's name as input.
examples.prompt: Write a simple Welcome {Name} program in Java that accepts the user's name as input.

chapters.title: Chapter 3: Controlling Code with Conditions and Loops
chapters.goal: Learn how to apply control structures in order to build more advanced applications that make use of logic and iteration.

examples.title: If Statement
examples.description: Create a Java program that displays a game's level if a condition is met.

prompts.prompt: Write a Java program without input that prints 'Novice Level' if the number variable is less than 10.
Update the code to add an else to print 'Expert Level' and update the variable to fit that criterion.
Add an else if for an 'Intermediate Level'.

examples.title: Ternary Operator
examples.description: Create a Java program that uses a ternary operator to print a game level.
examples.prompt: Use a ternary operator to print a game level as novice, intermediate, or expert based on a number variable.
response: int levelNumber = 17; // change this value to test

examples.title: Switch/Case Statement
examples.description: Create a Java program that displays the status of a process based on a number variable.
examples.prompt: Use a switch statement to evaluate a status number variable and print 'Starting' for 1, 'Processing' for 2, 'Ready' for 3, and 'Unknown' as default.

examples.title: While/Do-While Loop
examples.description: Create a Java program that uses while and do-while loops to print numbers.

prompts.prompt: Write a coffee order program using a while loop to print the status and increment until it reaches 100.
Change the code to use a do-while loop instead of a while loop.

examples.title: For Loop
examples.description: Create a Java program that loops through numbers or items in a list and prints each one.

prompts.prompt: Use a for loop to increment a lap number variable and print each lap.
Update the for loop to decrement the lap instead.
Write an intro for loop to print a status list of 'Starting', 'Processing', 'Finished'.

examples.title: Pizza Order
examples.description: Write a simple program in Java for ordering pizza with 3 kinds of pizza options.
examples.prompt: Write an intro Java pizza order program that offers 3 kinds of pizza, a user chooses which pizza, and the order is displayed back.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: Calling in the Functions
chapters.goal: Break down complicated programs into functions using static methods and learn about arguments, return types, and exception handling.

chapters.title: Chapter 5: Thinking in Objects
chapters.goal: Build more complex applications that require object-oriented techniques to encapsulate data and behavior.

chapters.title: Chapter 6: Testing with AI Confidence
chapters.goal: Learn how to get AI help to write unit tests to test and verify code for correctness.

chapters.title: Chapter 7: Organizing AI into Collections
chapters.goal: Introduction to collections that shows how to make use of the built-in data structures in the Java libraries to store and search for information easily.

chapters.title: Chapter 8: Gotta Collect Them All
chapters.goal: Coverage of the more advanced collection types in Java to store and retrieve information more efficiently.

chapters.title: Chapter 9: Mastering Streams with AI
chapters.goal: Example applications that show off the Java stream library for processing collections of data. Will cover functional programing concepts, lambdas, and parallel processing.

chapters.title: Chapter 10: Project: Smart Task Juggler
chapters.goal: A sample JavaFX application created using an agent programming approach. Will deconstruct the generated code to explain how JavaFX applications are built and how they can easily be modified and extended.

chapters.title: Chapter 11: Project: AI-Powered Resume Reviewer
chapters.goal: An agentic Spring AI sample application that will show how easy it is to build web applications in Java that communicates with ChatGPT.

chapters.title: Chapter 12: Project: Mobile Voice Journal
chapters.goal: A mobile application that will allow the reader to record notes and make use of AI to summarize, reflect on, and rewrite the entry.
